categories.name: Tantra Yoga Sanskrit: Asana Names, Meanings & Translations
categories.description: Learn accurate Sanskrit names for common asanas with their literal meanings and standard English translations, to build clear, confident cueing.

subcategories.name: Standing & Transitional Asanas

subcategories.name: Seated, Prone & Supine Asanas

questions.question: What is the standard English for “Tāḍāsana”?
questions.hint: Think tall, steady, grounded.
questions.explanation: Tāḍa means 'mountain.' Tāḍāsana is the neutral standing shape with steady, rooted legs and an upright spine. It's commonly the starting point for standing sequences.

questions.question: Translate “Vṛkṣāsana.”
questions.hint: Branches, balance, one foot rooted.
questions.explanation: Vṛkṣa means 'tree.' The posture cultivates balance with one foot rooted like a trunk and the other placed on the inner leg. Hands often come together overhead like branches.

questions.question: What does “Trikoṇāsana” translate to?
questions.hint: Three sides, long lines.
questions.explanation: Trikoṇa means 'triangle.' The pose creates triangular shapes through the legs and torso. It's a staple lateral extension posture.

questions.question: English name for “Vīrabhadrāsana I”?
questions.hint: Named after a fierce warrior aspect.
questions.explanation: Vīrabhadra is a mythic warrior. Vīrabhadrāsana I features a lunge with squared hips and arms overhead. It's a foundational strength posture.

questions.question: English name for “Vīrabhadrāsana II”?
questions.hint: Arms wide, hips open to the side.
questions.explanation: Warrior II opens the hips to the long edge of the mat, arms extended. It develops stamina and focus with a steady gaze over the front hand.

questions.question: English name for “Vīrabhadrāsana III”?
questions.hint: Balance on one leg, torso parallel.
questions.explanation: Warrior III is a balancing pose on one leg with the torso and back leg in one long line. It trains stability and focus.

questions.question: Translate “Utkatāsana.”
questions.hint: Imagine sitting back toward an invisible seat.
questions.explanation: Utkata means 'fierce' or 'intense.' The posture is popularly called Chair Pose due to the hips sitting back and arms reaching forward or up.

questions.question: English for “Uttānāsana”?
questions.hint: Fold from the hips, long spine.
questions.explanation: Uttāna means 'intense stretch' or 'extended.' In Uttānāsana you hinge forward from the hips, lengthening the posterior chain.

questions.question: Translate “Ardha Uttānāsana.”
questions.hint: Halfway lift lengthens the spine parallel to the floor.
questions.explanation: Ardha means 'half.' Ardha Uttānāsana is the halfway lift: spine long, hands often on shins or blocks. It prepares the back for deeper folds.

questions.question: What is “Parivṛtta Trikoṇāsana” in English?
questions.hint: Twist in the triangle shape.
questions.explanation: Parivṛtta means 'revolved.' This is the twisting counterpart to Triangle, emphasizing spinal rotation and hamstring length.

questions.question: English for “Pārśvakoṇāsana.”
questions.hint: Long side waist from back heel to fingertips.
questions.explanation: Pārśva means 'side' and koṇa means 'angle.' The pose creates a long diagonal line through the side body.

questions.question: Translate “Ardha Chandrāsana.”
questions.hint: Balance with torso open to the side.
questions.explanation: Chandra means 'moon.' Ardha Chandrāsana balances on one leg with the torso opening laterally, often with the top arm reaching upward.

questions.question: English for “Utthita Hasta Pādāṅguṣṭhāsana”?
questions.hint: Think: hand catches big toe while standing.
questions.explanation: Utthita means 'extended,' hasta 'hand,' pādāṅguṣṭha 'big toe.' It's a challenging standing balance with a leg extended.

questions.question: Translate “Prasārita Pādottānāsana.”
questions.hint: Wide stance, fold from hips.
questions.explanation: Prasārita means 'spread' or 'wide.' With feet wide, you hinge forward to lengthen hamstrings and spine.

questions.question: English for “Garuḍāsana.”
questions.hint: Arms and legs wrap like wings.
questions.explanation: Garuḍa is 'eagle.' The pose crosses legs and wraps arms to build focus and open the upper back.

questions.question: Translate “Naṭarājāsana.”
questions.hint: Lord of Dance—grace and backbend.
questions.explanation: Naṭarāja is Shiva as Lord of Dance. The pose is a standing balance with a backbend and a lifted, held foot.

questions.question: English for “Ūrdhva Hastāsana.”
questions.hint: Arms sweep up, ribs soft.
questions.explanation: Ūrdhva means 'upward.' This straightforward reach organizes shoulder flexion and length through the side body.

questions.question: Translate “Añjaneyāsana.”
questions.hint: Back knee down, chest lifted.
questions.explanation: Añjaneya is a name for Hanuman. The posture is a low lunge emphasizing hip flexor opening and heart lift; often called Crescent Lunge.

questions.question: English for “Parivṛtta Pārśvakoṇāsana.”
questions.hint: Twist toward the front leg.
questions.explanation: Parivṛtta means 'revolved.' This twisting lunge integrates rotation with leg strength and balance.

questions.question: Translate “Pādāṅguṣṭhāsana.”
questions.hint: Two fingers hook the big toes.
questions.explanation: Pādāṅguṣṭha means 'big toe.' From standing, you fold and hold the big toes to deepen hamstring length.

questions.question: English for “Pādahastāsana.”
questions.hint: Hands slide under the feet.
questions.explanation: Pādahasta means 'hand-to-foot.' It's a standing forward fold variation with palms under the soles to intensify the stretch.

questions.question: Translate “Utkaṭa Koṇāsana.”
questions.hint: Wide stance, knees bent, hips open.
questions.explanation: Often called Goddess, this fierce-angle squat opens the hips with external rotation and a strong spine.

questions.question: English for “Parighāsana.”
questions.hint: Kneeling side bend with extended leg.
questions.explanation: Parigha means 'bar/gate-latch.' The pose creates a lateral opening of the torso over an extended leg from a kneeling base.

questions.question: Translate “Adho Mukha Śvānāsana.”
questions.hint: Inverted V-shape, hands and feet press.
questions.explanation: Adho means 'down,' mukha 'face,' śvāna 'dog.' This is a mild inversion and key transition in vinyāsa sequences.

questions.question: English for “Ūrdhva Mukha Śvānāsana.”
questions.hint: Chest forward, thighs lifted.
questions.explanation: Ūrdhva means 'upward.' This backbend opens the chest and engages arms while legs are active and lifted from the mat.

questions.question: Translate “Caturaṅga Daṇḍāsana.”
questions.hint: Low plank with elbows at 90°.
questions.explanation: Caturaṅga means 'four-limbed,' daṇḍa 'staff.' It's the controlled low push-up position linking vinyāsa flows.

questions.question: English for “Hasta Uttānāsana.”
questions.hint: Similar to Upward Salute; arms reach high.
questions.explanation: Hasta means 'hands,' uttāna 'intense stretch.' It lengthens the side body and prepares for backbends.

questions.question: Translate “Ardha Uttkaṭa āsana” (common variant name).
questions.hint: Hips back, smaller knee bend than full Chair.
questions.explanation: In practice, 'Half Chair' cues a lighter squat while maintaining spinal length. It is used as a step toward Utkatāsana.

questions.question: English for “Parśvottānāsana.”
questions.hint: Square the hips toward the front leg.
questions.explanation: Parśva means 'side,' uttāna 'intense stretch.' The pose targets hamstrings with a long spine over the front leg.

questions.question: Translate “Sukhasana.”
questions.hint: Comfortable cross‑legged seat.
questions.explanation: Sukha means 'ease' or 'comfort.' It's a simple cross‑legged meditation seat that encourages a tall, relaxed spine.

questions.question: English name for “Padmāsana.”
questions.hint: Classic meditative seat with crossed feet on thighs.
questions.explanation: Padma means 'lotus.' The posture symbolizes stability and openness, traditionally used for meditation.

questions.question: What is “Siddhāsana” in English?
questions.hint: A classic meditation seat alternative to Lotus.
questions.explanation: Siddha means 'accomplished' or 'adept.' The heel placement supports an upright, steady spine for breathwork and meditation.

questions.question: Translate “Vajrāsana.”
questions.hint: Kneeling on shins; sit back on heels.
questions.explanation: Vajra means 'thunderbolt/diamond.' Sitting on the heels aids digestion and steady breath after meals in some traditions.

questions.question: English for “Vīrāsana.”
questions.hint: Kneel and sit between the heels.
questions.explanation: Vīra means 'hero.' The pose opens quadriceps and lengthens the spine from a kneeling base.

questions.question: Translate “Daṇḍāsana.”
questions.hint: Legs extended, spine upright.
questions.explanation: Daṇḍa means 'staff.' The extended legs and active feet provide a base for seated forward bends and twists.

questions.question: English for “Paścimottānāsana.”
questions.hint: Fold over the long back body (west side).
questions.explanation: Paścima means 'west/back of the body.' The pose stretches hamstrings and lengthens the spine forward over the legs.

questions.question: Translate “Pūrvottānāsana.”
questions.hint: Reverse table to straight‑leg plank.
questions.explanation: Pūrva means 'east/front of body.' This backbend strengthens posterior shoulders while opening the chest and front body.

questions.question: English for “Baddha Koṇāsana.”
questions.hint: Soles of the feet together, knees wide.
questions.explanation: Baddha means 'bound' and koṇa 'angle.' The posture externally rotates the hips and lengthens the inner thighs.

questions.question: Translate “Upaviṣṭha Koṇāsana.”
questions.hint: Legs wide, fold forward from hips.
questions.explanation: Upaviṣṭha means 'seated.' This pose stretches inner legs and hamstrings while keeping the spine long.

questions.question: English for “Jānu Śīrṣāsana.”
questions.hint: One knee bends; fold over the extended leg.
questions.explanation: Jānu means 'knee' and śīrṣa 'head.' It combines hamstring length with a gentle twist toward the extended leg.

questions.question: Translate “Mārīchyāsana.”
questions.hint: Sage Marichi’s twist/bind variations.
questions.explanation: Named for the sage Marichi. The pose family involves twists and possible binds from a seated base to mobilize the spine.

questions.question: English for “Gomukhāsana.”
questions.hint: Knees stack; hands bind behind back.
questions.explanation: Gomukha means 'cow face.' The legs and arms position create symmetrical opening in hips and shoulders.

questions.question: Translate “Bharadvājāsana.”
questions.hint: Gentle seated twist variation.
questions.explanation: Named after the sage Bharadvaja. This twist encourages lift through the spine before rotation.

questions.question: English for “Ardha Matsyendrāsana.”
questions.correctAnswer: Half Lord of the Fishes Pose
questions.hint: Seated spinal twist; lift then rotate.
questions.explanation: Named for Matsyendra, a legendary yogi. The pose lengthens the spine and rotates to massage the abdominal organs.

questions.question: Translate “Balāsana.”
questions.hint: Resting fold with shins down.
questions.explanation: Bala means 'child.' It's a restorative posture that lengthens the back and encourages diaphragmatic breathing.

questions.question: English for “Bhujāṅgāsana.”
questions.hint: Prone backbend with elbows close.
questions.explanation: Bhujanga means 'cobra.' The pose strengthens the back while opening the chest, with pubic bone heavy on the mat.

questions.question: Translate “Śalabhāsana.”
questions.hint: Prone lift of chest and legs.
questions.explanation: Śalabha means 'locust.' It builds posterior chain strength and supports healthier backbends.

questions.question: English for “Dhanurāsana.”
questions.hint: Catch ankles; lift chest and thighs.
questions.explanation: Dhanura means 'bow.' The body forms a bow shape, stretching the entire front body while strengthening the back.

questions.question: Translate “Uṣṭrāsana.”
questions.hint: Tall kneeling backbend; hands to heels.
questions.explanation: Uṣṭra means 'camel.' It’s a deep front‑body opener that also strengthens the posterior chain and demands spinal integrity.

questions.question: English for “Setu Bandha Sarvāṅgāsana.”
questions.hint: Lift hips with shoulders grounded.
questions.explanation: Setu bandha means 'constructing a bridge.' This backbend strengthens glutes and hamstrings while opening the chest.

questions.question: Translate “Matsyāsana.”
questions.hint: Backbend with chest lifted, often legs in Lotus or straight.
questions.explanation: Matsya means 'fish.' The posture opens the throat and chest, countering long periods of forward bending.

questions.question: English for “Supta Baddha Koṇāsana.”
questions.hint: Lie back, soles together, knees wide.
questions.explanation: Supta means 'reclined.' This restorative posture gently opens the hips and encourages relaxed breathing.

questions.question: Translate “Pavanamuktāsana.”
questions.hint: Hug one or both knees to chest.
questions.explanation: Pavana means 'wind' and mukta 'release.' The pose massages the abdomen and can ease lower back tension.

questions.question: English for “Viparīta Karaṇī.”
questions.hint: Passive inversion with legs vertical.
questions.explanation: Viparīta means 'inverted' and karaṇī 'action.' It's a gentle inversion for drainage and relaxation.

questions.question: Translate “Śavāsana.”
questions.hint: Final rest lying flat and still.
questions.explanation: Śava means 'corpse.' The practice integrates the effects of the session and trains deep, wakeful relaxation.

questions.question: English for “Paripūrṇa Nāvāsana.”
questions.hint: Balance on sit bones; legs and torso form a V.
questions.explanation: Paripūrṇa means 'full/complete.' Boat Pose strengthens hip flexors and core while challenging breath control.

questions.question: Translate “Ardha Nāvāsana.”
questions.hint: Lower the legs/torso to intensify core work.
questions.explanation: Ardha means 'half.' Half Boat increases abdominal demand and teaches controlled spinal flexion.

questions.question: English for “Supta Vīrāsana.”
questions.hint: From Hero, recline back to the floor (or props).
questions.explanation: Supta means 'reclined.' It deeply lengthens the front thighs and challenges spinal extension; props are common for safety.
